results.snippet: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ASTRONAUT FARMER  (2007) Fly me to the moon: Billy Bob Thornton, left, plays Charles Farmer, a space-obsessed rancher who builds a rocket in his barn and plans to blast himself into orbit. Virginia Madsen is Audie, the adoring...
results.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ASTRONAUT FARMER (2007) Fly me to the moon: Billy Bob Thornton, left, plays Charles Farmer, a space-obsessed rancher who builds a rocket in his barn and plans to blast himself into orbit. Virginia Madsen is Audie, the adoring wife who supports his far-flung dreams long after a more sensible woman would have left. Not so enchanted with Farmer's scheme: the Federal Aviation Administration, the F.B.I. and NASA. The film's director, Michael Polish, demonstrates a ''taste for odd, resonant images,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The opening shots, of Farmer on horseback in his space suit, hint at a strangeness that the rest of the movie never quite lives up to, but it does have a visual freshness that makes the bromides and clich√©s palatable.'' 8 P.M. (Animal Planet, Discovery) AKC/EUKANUBA NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP 2008 More than 2,400 dogs from across the country compete for titles and $225,000 in prize money at this seventh annual competition held in Long Beach, Calif. Bob Goen is host, assisted by Lee Arnold, a dog show veteran, and Edd Bivin, an American Kennel Club judge; Leanza Cornett interviews owners, handlers and even a few dogs.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis launches after two-month delay caused by faulty fuel sensors; shuttle carries European science laboratory Columbus, which will attach to International Space Station during 11-day mission; drawing (M)

headline.main: Atlantis Heads for the Space Station to Deliver a Science Laboratory From Europe

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis dodged an approaching weather front and rumbled into space, carrying the European science laboratory Columbus to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis dodged an approaching weather front and rumbled into space on Thursday, carrying the European science laboratory Columbus to the International Space Station. Atlantis and its seven-member crew lifted off into a partly cloudy sky at 2:45 p.m. Eastern time from the Kennedy Space Center. With only a few technical problems to deal with, controllers kept an eye on the potential for rainy weather that could have blocked the flight.

headline.main: Astronaut's Health Problem Delays Spacewalk Mission

results.snippet: Hans Schlegel, a European Space Agency astronaut from Germany, will be replaced by Stanley G. Love on the delayed spacewalk.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts will delay by one day attaching a European science laboratory to the International Space Station because of an undisclosed health problem with one member of the space shuttle Atlantis' seven-man crew, NASA officials said Saturday. John Shannon, chairman of NASA's Mission Management Team, disclosed the problem and delay during a televised briefing from the Johnson Space Center in Houston. However, citing privacy issues, he refused to disclose the nature of the medical issue or the astronaut involved.

headline.main: Girardi Is Leaving A Lot Behind

results.snippet: As Joe Girardi prepares to embark on a new beginning as the Yankees’ manager, he is not sure when or if he will see his ailing father again.
results.lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi had tears in his eyes, tears that have been building for months, even years, and tears that were close to covering his face. But Girardi, the manager of the Yankees, stared upward, plowed through his thoughts and kept the tears from escaping. He held them back, for now, anyway. As Girardi raved about embarking on a new beginning with the Yankees, he meandered into an emotional discussion about a possible ending. After Girardi drives to Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday for spring training, he is not sure when or if he will see his ailing father again.

results.abstract: Benjamin Genocchio reviews Cuba: Artists Experience Their Country, exhibit at Hunterdon Museum of Art in Clinton, NJ; photos (M)
results.snippet: An exhibit at the Hunterdon Museum of Art, one of its largest ever, shows the depth of Cuban talent.
results.lead_paragraph: Back in 1992, when I visited Cuba to attend the Havana Biennale, I knew it was only a matter of time before the world took notice of the country's artists. The following year New York's Museum of Modern Art staged ''Latin American Artists of the 20th Century,'' a landmark event for the exposure of Cuban artists. Among them was Jos√© Bedia, who is also in the compelling show ''Cuba: Artists Experience Their Country,'' now at the Hunterdon Museum of Art. Mr. Bedia, who was 34 in 1993, painted outsize outline drawings of mythical figures influenced by African, Afro-Cuban and Native American religions and cosmology. Spirituality is still a part of his work, though after leaving Cuba for Mexico in 1993 he began making symbolic drawings that reflect on contemporary life, history and culture in his homeland. On display here is his drawing ''Isla Cimarrona'' (1994), a rough representation of Cuba as a dangerous and forbidding place. (Cimarr√≥n means wild in Spanish.)

results.abstract: NASA officials say astronauts aboard International Space station are ready for critical spacewalk to prepare European Columbus science module to be attached to station; walk was delayed because of illness of German astronaut; photo (M)

headline.main: New Shuttle Team Ready For Walk After Day's Delay

results.snippet: NASA officials said that everything was ready for astronauts to prepare the European Columbus science module to be attached to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station spent Sunday moving supplies from the shuttle Atlantis and preparing for a spacewalk delayed by the illness of a German astronaut. NASA officials said Sunday that everything was ready for a critical Monday spacewalk in which astronauts will prepare the European Columbus science module to be removed from the shuttle's cargo bay and attached to the station.

results.abstract: American astronaut Daniel Tani, during interview on NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams, says he and crew actually watch program; NASA regularly transmits podcasts of Nightly News, minus commercials, to International Space Station; photo (S)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: NBC NIGHTLY NEWS WITH BRIAN WILLIAMS (TV PROGRAM)

results.snippet: Network newscasts have been known to go to great lengths to find new viewers, but the “NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams” has taken that search to outer space.
results.lead_paragraph: Network newscasts have been known to go to great lengths to find new viewers, but the ''NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams'' has taken that search to a place where few, if any, anchors, have gone before: outer space. In an interview from the International Space Station on Friday via satellite, an American astronaut, Daniel M. Tani, right, said he and his crew members ''actually watch the 'NBC Nightly News.' '' Mr. Tani was responding to a question from an NBC correspondent, Tom Costello, about how the space station crew stays current on world events. The network said that Mr. Costello had been unaware that NASA regularly transmits podcasts of ''Nightly News'' (minus commercials) to the space station. The astronauts also receive news updates from The Houston Chronicle, one of NASA's hometown newspapers. Brett Holey, director of ''Nightly News,'' said NBC began making the program available to the space station in early 2006. It did so, he said, after a ''psychological support scientist'' for NASA suggested the transmission as a way to ease isolation.

results.abstract: Astronauts from space shuttle Atlantis attach Columbus science module to International Space Station; module adds 2,600 cubic feet of volume to space station, doubling its research ability, and is European Space Agency's primary contribution to project; photo (M)

headline.main: European Lab Attached to Space Station

results.snippet: Astronauts placed the crown jewel of Europe’s contribution to the International Space Station into its permanent setting on Monday with the attachment of the Columbus science module.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts placed the crown jewel of Europe's contribution to the International Space Station into its permanent setting on Monday with the attachment of the Columbus science module. On a seven-hour, 58-minute spacewalk, two astronauts and a robot arm guided the Columbus out of the cargo bay of the space shuttle Atlantis and affixed it to station.

results.snippet: The astronauts spent six hours and 45 minutes outside the station removing a spent refrigerator-size tank and replacing it with one full of pressurized nitrogen, in addition to performing other tasks.
results.lead_paragraph: Two spacewalkers, including a German astronaut who was too ill to venture outside the International Space Station earlier this week, replaced a large nitrogen tank on the station on Wednesday. The astronauts, from the crew of the space shuttle Atlantis, spent six hours and 45 minutes outside the station removing a spent refrigerator-size tank and replacing it with one full of pressurized nitrogen, in addition to performing several other tasks.

results.abstract: Shuttle Atlantis leaves International Space Station and heads home for planned landing, clearing way for Defense Department effort to shoot down failed spy satellite; out-of-control spy satellite is expected to crash to earth early next month; is carrying half-ton of toxic rocket fuel that could harm people if it crashes in populated area (M)

headline.main: Satellite Shooting Is Next As Shuttle Heads Home

results.snippet: The shuttle Atlantis has cleared the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite.
results.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Atlantis left the International Space Station on Monday and headed home for a planned Wednesday landing, clearing the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite. The shuttle and its seven-member crew left the station after almost nine days of joint operations topped by installing the $2 billion Columbus science laboratory of the European Space Agency.

results.snippet: Hours after the satellite shootdown, doubts on a national treasure.
results.lead_paragraph: Hours after China voiced discontent over the United States's satellite shootdown, Scientific American doubted that their national treasure could be viewed from space:

results.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's latest Texas ad focuses on how the promises of politicians are "better done than said."

headline.main: Clinton Goes Up With New Ads

results.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton's latest Texas ad focuses on how the promises of politicians are "better done than said."
results.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has not one, not two, but three new TV ads out today. One takes a definitive Texas angle, the others play to Ohio's emphasis on jobs, jobs, jobs.

headline.main: Starship Kimchi: A Bold Taste Goes Where It Has Never Gone Before

results.snippet: South Korea has devoted several years and millions of dollars to make a cabbage dish suitable to go into space with its first astronaut in April.
results.lead_paragraph: After South Korea began sending soldiers to fight beside American forces in Vietnam, President Park Chung-hee made an unusual plea. He wrote to President Lyndon Johnson to say that his troops were miserable, desperate for kimchi, the fermented cabbage dish that Koreans savor with almost every meal. Chung Il-kwon, then the prime minister, delivered the letter to Washington. When he traveled overseas, he told Johnson, he longed for kimchi more than for his wife. The president acquiesced, financing the delivery of canned kimchi to the battlefield.

results.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column compares Sen Hillary Clinton to Ohio, which she describes as no-frills kind of place that is suspicious of glamour; is amazed that one of best-known people on planet manages to become boring candidate; says rival Sen Barack Obama is on trajectory that is difficult to beat (M)
results.snippet: If Hillary Clinton can win Ohio  and if she doesn’t, she is as cooked as reheated risotto  it will be because people here worry that Barack Obama is getting show-offy.
results.lead_paragraph: If Hillary Clinton were a state, she'd be Ohio.
